2.4 CSF shunt infections 
Type of Infection 
First Line (with Dosage 
and Duration) 
Alternative (with 
dosage and Duration) 
Comments 
CNS device 
infections 
in stable patients  
 
 
 
 
 
Vancomycin 25 mg/kg IV 
stat followed by 
15mg/kg q 8-12h   
+ 
Ceftazidime 2g IV q8h  
Or 
Cefepime 2g IV q8h 
 
 
 
For confirmed shunt 
infections, the shunt 
should be removed and a 
temporary external 
ventricular drain inserted. 
The shunt should be sent 
for cultures. 
 
Adjunctive intraventricular 
antibiotics are not 
routinely necessary for 
treatment of CSF shunt 
infections. 
Intraventricular antibiotics 
may be required for: 
infections that are 
refractory to appropriate 
systemic antibiotic therapy,  
infections caused by highly 
resistant organisms 
susceptible only to 
antimicrobials with poor 
CSF penetration, and  
infections in which the 
shunt cannot be removed.  
When intraventricular 
antibiotics are used, they 
should be administered in 
combination with 
intravenous therapy. 
 
Uncomplicated shunt 
infections can be treated 
with a total course of 7–12 
days of intra-ventricular 
and intravenous 
antibiotics. 
 
Complicated shunt 
infections can be treated 
with 2 weeks intra-
ventricular (given OD) and 
3 weeks intravenous 
antibiotics.
